label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, June 21, 1943
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, regarding her job transfer to London, England, relaying news of the children’s summer at Watch Hill, and delivering news of their friends.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
M 6 22 43
R 7 2 43
June 21st '45
Dear Sidney, 
It is a very hot night and I am sitting in my bedroom
with the air conditioner battling the temperature, and inspite of all
the hard work the machine is doing the thermometer registers 90[percent].
To-day a cable came through from London giving my job
description for my pastport so it look sas though I really will get
off sometime in July for London. I hope it will turn out to be as interes
-ting and exciting as I think it will be. Considering that the next
five months should settle the europeans war[,]I feel they should be
very exciting days ahead. I hope I shall not be dissapointed and
very lonely. There is always that side to it ofcourse.
If I could be going Pacif_icwards in_stead of the other
way I would ofcourse like it a whole lot better. I do wish the Navy
would not have such foolish rigid rules.
Working for David will be nic_e,because he is understanding,
and will allow me to resign if need be shou_ld you be transf_ered home.
L ater on if the London offic_e decreases I h_ope to get sent to the
other sid_e of the world to do a job f_or the Jap campaine. My be our
paths will c_ross bef_ore the war is oger , I am always hoping that some
h_ow they will .
I have entered Landine in the Metarie Park Country Day
School at Olive's advice- for next wint_er. I have taken three of her
rooms for the kids[,]and I think it will all work out very well.
Rose will of course be the roving acomplice that attends to everything.
The children, the Plantation, sending forg otten articles[,]and attending
to everything. I must say without Rose I would not have the same feeling
of perfect confidence that I have knowing she is there ready for
anything. 
Miss Evans wrote me to-day the kids were wonderful,
enjoying lif_e to the fullest, that Landine was no problem at all ,
and that everything wasrunning smoolthly,and that they were all very
happy.- including Honey.
I am so glad their summer is such a success.
I expect to go over on a queen boat sometime next month. Iam
allowed 175 lbs. and I expect to live at Claridges when I get there.
There are no servants to be had for a house, and only at a hotel can you
get bathtowels and have your shoes cleaned and clothes pressed. So I think
I shall stay there untel something else turns up, somebody might invite m
me to visit then although I doubt it. I expect to have the same type of
Job over there,but perhaps being a little closer to the front it will have
more zest and excitement than Washington. I am hoping so. The whole
thing is a gamble and I may be bitterly disspaointed. The old refrain-
"not_hing ventured nothing gaind_d" is what [I] believe. As long as I
c ant get to H a waii I don t mu_c_h care where I am,so I might as well
t_ry and get as muc_h interest and thrill out of the war as possible, so Il
think being over there is better than here- so thats that.
It is quite a step to take all by myselfas I have never traveledalone bef
-fore. I feel I have gotten all there is to get out of Washington after
a year of it[,]and a change of scene is quite a thrill. My feelings are
very mixed[,]and have moment_s whe[n?] wonder whethe_r have made
the right discision.
[End Page 1]
2
Making up on[e's] mind all alone, deciding what is right and wrong, and
then going ahead with it is awfully upsetting. I dont like it at all.
I am truly lost without you. I feel so alone and solitary. No one to
talk a thing over with or discuss it with. Just oneself, ones own self 
in bed alone,and I am tortured with doubt and qualms. Its very painful.
Well its decided now,and come whatmay I am underway. It wont be long
now till I get off. Going furthur away from you - furthur in miles in dis-
tance for mail is not a pleasant thought, but then there is no really
pleasant thought unless I was taking a boat to Honolulu,which is my idea
of getting to heaven , for it would be heaven if I could see you again_
N OW,without waiting till the war with Japan has come to an end.
I went to Chevey Chas_e yesterday. Marion Hollins was with
me and we lunched with Edith Munson and her brother, Lester, and some
one called ADAMS. They golfed and I tennised,and we had a lovely day of 
exercise and sunshine. They all came back to my house for supper after-
wards and Rose had cold lobsters,and salad,and ice cream and it was deli-
cious. Murry and Lanier came too, and Maurice Fatio who has just come
to Washington. We had a very early evening,and Marion and I tried to sleep 
and get cool in the airconditioned bedroom but it was as hot as now [percent]90.
The summeer is here with a vengeance and you drip from morning to night. 
Perspiration pores from ones brow every minute of the day[,]and everything
sticks.
Marion tells me San Pedro is a very dreary spot. Not at all
attractive. Its that flat part between Los Angeles and La Jolla near the
oil wells on the way south. Nothing like as attractive as La Jolla or
anything like Ranch_o SantaFe, or Del[M]onty, Carmel etc etc or around
SantaBarbarbara. Marion is living in a house on Cypress Point Golf Course
now[,]and says she has had a terrific reel estate season this year. Every
one is buying.
Mrs James Dunn who was at Chevy Chase yesterday tells me
that nothing in California can coppare to Hawaii. She has lived in both
places and claims there is no comparison. You ahve the vegetation where
you are. No dust storms or aridness,and far more even climate. I think
you must find the house,so when the war is over I can move out and join
you with the kids. I am told the schools there are excellent too.
Hawaii is as good a base as any because with aviation what it is going to
be after this war--- we can go any place any time very cheap in no time.
Distance will be nothing. All of us will have heliacopters too.
I am looking forward to the world when this is over because I think it
will beas different as the horse and buggy days were to the automobile.
I am looking forward to your next letter and hope it will arrive
to-morrow. Your last was June 1oth.
Lots of love my darling and I shall arrange a telephone call
probably to-morrow.
All my love-
Gertrude
[End Page 2]
